summary: On September 25, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a final judgment against Taurean Lamar Thomas, Jr., a Shreveport, Louisiana man convicted of second-degree battery and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in New Orleans, Texas on June 22, 2016, Thomas was found guilty of second degree battery in violation of the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC alleges that Thomas was also found liable as a felon in possession of an airsoft toy gun, which he claimed to have obtained from a California-based felon, and that he used the gun to commit a series of felonies, including a felony theft in 1991, armed robbery in 2003, and a felony burglary of an inhabited dwelling in 2011.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, Thomas consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the federal securities laws, and orders him to pay a $1,000 civil penalty and a $100,000 officer-and-director bar.  In addition, Thomas agreed to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years and ordered to pay disgorgement of $2,078.71, prejudgment interest of $959.95, a civil penalty of $10,000, and to be restrained and/or restrained from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an attorney.  Thomas also agreed to a five-year, post-verdict suspension of his previous felony conviction for simple burglary.  He also agreed not to participate in the issuance of a subpoena for a copy of the Commission's Rules of Practice, which are subject to court approval.  On November 1, 2016 the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against Thomas, charging him with violating Section 15(b)(5) and Rule 15b2-1 thereunder, and with violating Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4)-3 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 206(3)-8 thereunder and with aiding and abetting Thomas' violations of Section 17(a)(1) and (3) of Securities Act Section 10-b) and Rules 12b-20, 13a-1, and (4) thereunder of the Exchange Act and Rule 17a-3 thereunder; and with respect to the registration provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and (d) of
